The Climate Change Controversy

Recently, a group of 50 scientists from around the world released a comprehensive new report on global change that concluded that chances are good that global warming is not the result of human-related greenhouse gas emissions.

Strangely, this report, which cites thousands of peer-reviewed articles, has been ignored by the United Nations-sponsored panel on climate change. Also ignored were this group’s findings that “no empirical evidence exists to substantiate the claim that 2°C of warming presents a threat to planetary ecologies or environments.” Finally, this report contends that no convincing case been made that “warming will be more economically costly than an equivalent cooling.”

The group that produced the ignored report is the Nongovernmental International Panel on Climate Change (NIPCC). In contrast to the United Nations’ Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change (IPCC), which is government-sponsored, politically motivated, and inclined to believe that climate change is a problem that demands immediate U.N. action, the NIPCC has “no formal attachment to or sponsorship from any government or governmental agency” and is “wholly independent of political pressures and influences.” For this reason, NIPCC is unlikely to be predisposed to “present politically motivated conclusions or policy recommendations.”

The 1200-page report produced by NIPCC, Climate Change Reconsidered II: Physical Science, found that even if the “concentration of atmospheric carbon dioxide were to double,” the “warming that would occur would likely be modest and cause no net harm to the global environment or to human well-being.” In short, the report rebuts the findings of the United Nations’ IPCC, which the NIPCC authors claim are in “contradiction of the scientific method.” NIPCC argues that the IPCC report assumes that its hypothesis that “dangerous global warming is resulting, or will result, from human-related greenhouse gas emissions” is correct, even though there is no evidence backing up that hypothesis. Instead of proving that hypothesis, what the IPCC report does is collect evidence and make plausible arguments in favor of a hypothesis it has already accepted without sufficient proof.

The NIPCC report refutes many of the key findings of the United Nations’ report including that “a doubling of atmospheric CO2 would cause warming between 3°C and 6°C” and that “CO2 caused an atmospheric warming of at least 0.3° over the past 15 years.”

It is the contention of the NIPCC authors that the United Nations panel made “climate change into a political issue long before the science was sufficiently advanced to inform policy makers.” The authors further argue that “most government signatories to the UN’s Framework Convention on Climate Change have deferred to the monopoly advice of the IPCC in setting their national climate change policies.” One result of governmental policies based on what NIPCC authors claim is deeply flawed science, “has been the expenditure of hundreds of billions of dollars implementing energy policies that now appear to have been unnecessary, or at least ill-timed and ineffective.”
